canonical_explanation.text: Data is information collected about things. We can show data using pictographs, bar graphs, and tables. A pictograph uses small pictures to show numbers. A bar graph uses bars of different heights to show numbers. A table uses rows and columns to organise data. We can read these to find out how many, which is most, which is least, and compare amounts. We can also draw simple conclusions like which item is most popular or least popular.
rules: A pictograph uses pictures or symbols to represent data. Each picture stands for one or more items.
A bar graph uses bars to show data. Taller bars mean larger numbers.
A table arranges data in rows and columns so it is easy to read.
To find the most, look for the largest number, tallest bar, or most pictures.
To find the least, look for the smallest number, shortest bar, or fewest pictures.
We can compare two groups by looking at their numbers and finding which is more or less.
We can draw simple conclusions such as which item is the favourite or which has the fewest.

questions.question_text: A pictograph shows favourite fruits. Apple has 5 pictures, Banana has 3 pictures, and Mango has 7 pictures. Each picture stands for 1 child. How many children like Banana?
A bar graph shows the number of birds seen in a park. The bar for Sparrow reaches 8, the bar for Crow reaches 5, and the bar for Pigeon reaches 10. How many pigeons were seen?
A pictograph shows toys sold. Car has 6 pictures, Doll has 9 pictures, Ball has 4 pictures. Each picture stands for 2 toys. How many dolls were sold?
A table shows books read by children. Ria read 7, Sam read 4, Dev read 9. How many books did Ria read?
A pictograph shows flowers in a garden. Rose has 10 pictures, Lily has 6 pictures, Sunflower has 8 pictures. Each picture stands for 1 flower. Which flower is the most?
A bar graph shows stickers collected. Amit has a bar reaching 12, Priya has a bar reaching 8, Kabir has a bar reaching 15. How many more stickers does Kabir have than Priya?
A table shows the number of pencils each child has. Neha: 6, Rohan: 11, Meera: 3, Jay: 8. How many pencils do Neha and Jay have together?

A pictograph shows favourite colours chosen by children. Red has 12 pictures, Blue has 4 pictures, Green has 8 pictures, Yellow has 6 pictures. Each picture stands for 1 child. Which colour is the most popular?
A bar graph shows ice cream flavours chosen by 30 children. Chocolate bar reaches 14, Vanilla bar reaches 9, Strawberry bar reaches 7. Which flavour should the shop make the most of?
A table shows marks scored by 4 students. Anu: 45, Binu: 38, Cinu: 50, Dinu: 42. What is the difference between the highest and lowest marks?
A pictograph shows animals at a farm. Cow has 4 pictures, Hen has 8 pictures, Goat has 5 pictures. Each picture stands for 3 animals. How many hens are there?
A table shows the number of children absent each day. Monday: 3, Tuesday: 5, Wednesday: 2, Thursday: 6, Friday: 4. On which two days were a total of 7 children absent?
A bar graph shows trees planted by four classes. Class A: 10, Class B: 15, Class C: 7, Class D: 15. How many classes planted the most trees?
A table shows the number of glasses of water drunk by children. Asha: 8, Kiran: 3, Farah: 6, Gopal: 5. Asha says she drinks the most water. Is she correct?

A bar graph shows the number of students who walk, take a bus, or ride a car to school. Walk bar reaches 20, Bus bar reaches 15, Car bar reaches 10. How many students are shown in the graph altogether?
A pictograph shows pets owned by children. Dog has 6 pictures, Cat has 4 pictures, Fish has 3 pictures. Each picture stands for 1 pet. The number of dogs is ___.
A table shows the number of children in each hobby group. Dance: 9, Painting: 12, Music: 7. The number of children in the Painting group is ___.
A bar graph shows runs scored. Ravi: 20, Sita: 35, Tom: 25. The player who scored the least runs is ___.
A table shows cupcakes baked by three friends. Anu: 10, Bela: 16, Cathy: 10. Bela baked ___ more cupcakes than Anu.
A pictograph shows fruits picked. Orange has 7 pictures, Apple has 5 pictures, Guava has 9 pictures. Each picture stands for 2 fruits. The total number of apples picked is ___.
A table shows pages read by four students. Pia: 30, Qasim: 18, Rina: 25, Sunil: 40. The total pages read by Pia and Rina together is ___.
A bar graph shows the number of children who like different sports. Cricket: 18, Football: 12, Tennis: 5, Badminton: 9. The least popular sport is ___.
A table shows toy cars owned by children. Arjun: 14, Bhanu: 8, Charan: 11. The difference between the most and least toy cars is ___.
A pictograph shows votes for class monitor. Leela has 12 pictures, Mohan has 8 pictures, Nita has 15 pictures. Each picture stands for 1 vote. The winner of the election is ___.
A bar graph shows the number of butterflies spotted each day. Monday: 9, Tuesday: 14, Wednesday: 6, Thursday: 11. On Tuesday and Wednesday together, ___ butterflies were spotted.
A pictograph shows balloons at a party. Red has 8 pictures, Blue has 5 pictures, Green has 3 pictures. Each picture stands for 1 balloon. There are 5 blue balloons. True or False?
In a bar graph, a taller bar always means a smaller number. True or False?
A table shows children's ages. Riya: 7, Karan: 8, Pooja: 6. Karan is the oldest. True or False?
A bar graph shows marbles. Ali: 10, Ben: 15, Cara: 10. Ali and Cara have an equal number of marbles. True or False?
A pictograph shows crayons. Box A has 9 pictures, Box B has 6 pictures, Box C has 12 pictures. Each picture stands for 1 crayon. Box B has the most crayons. True or False?
A table shows apples picked. Day 1: 14, Day 2: 8, Day 3: 20. More apples were picked on Day 1 than Day 2. True or False?
A bar graph shows snacks sold at a fair. Popcorn: 30, Chips: 18, Juice: 25. Since Popcorn sold the most, we can say Popcorn is the most popular snack at the fair. True or False?
A table shows books borrowed from a library. Story books: 22, Science books: 10, Art books: 15. We can conclude that children prefer Science books the most. True or False?
A pictograph shows stamps collected. Ravi has 5 pictures, Geeta has 7 pictures. Each picture stands for 3 stamps. Ravi has 15 stamps. True or False?
A bar graph shows goals scored. Team A: 4, Team B: 9, Team C: 6. The difference between Team B and Team A is 3. True or False?
A pictograph shows favourite vegetables. Each picture stands for 1 child. Carrot: 5 pictures, Peas: 8 pictures, Potato: 3 pictures, Beans: 6 pictures. Match each vegetable to its count.
A table shows the number of storybooks on each shelf. Shelf A: 12, Shelf B: 7, Shelf C: 20, Shelf D: 15. Match each shelf to the number of storybooks.
A bar graph shows children's heights in cm. Anu: 48, Balu: 42, Chitra: 50, Deepa: 45. Match each child to a description.

A pictograph shows sandwiches sold each day. Each picture stands for 2 sandwiches. Monday: 3 pictures, Tuesday: 5 pictures, Wednesday: 4 pictures, Thursday: 6 pictures. Match each day to the total sandwiches sold.
A table shows points scored by teams. Red: 25, Blue: 40, Green: 18, Yellow: 33. Match each comparison to the correct answer.
A bar graph shows drinks sold at a canteen. Tea: 28, Coffee: 15, Milk: 35, Juice: 22. Match each conclusion to the correct drink.

match_pairs.left: Drink sold more than Tea but less than Milk

questions.question_text: A table shows the number of rainy days in four months. June: 10, July: 18, August: 14, September: 6. Match each question to its answer.

match_pairs.left: Total rainy days in June and September

questions.question_text: A pictograph shows children who chose different games for Sports Day. Running: 11 pictures, Jumping: 7 pictures, Relay: 14 pictures, Skipping: 9 pictures. Each picture stands for 1 child. Match each conclusion to true or false.

match_pairs.left: Relay is the most chosen game
Running is less popular than Skipping
Jumping is the least chosen game
More children chose Skipping than Running

questions.question_text: A table shows the number of shells collected. Anu: 8, Bina: 15, Charu: 5, Diya: 12. Arrange the children from the fewest shells to the most shells.
A pictograph shows kites flown. Red: 3 pictures, Blue: 7 pictures, Green: 5 pictures, Yellow: 1 picture. Each picture stands for 1 kite. Arrange the colours from the most kites to the fewest kites.
A bar graph shows children who play different instruments. Piano: 9, Guitar: 14, Drums: 6, Flute: 11. Arrange the instruments from least popular to most popular.
A table shows the number of visitors to a zoo each day. Monday: 40, Tuesday: 25, Wednesday: 50, Thursday: 35. Arrange the days from the most visitors to the fewest visitors.

A pictograph shows cookies sold each day. Each picture stands for 5 cookies. Monday: 4 pictures, Tuesday: 2 pictures, Wednesday: 6 pictures, Thursday: 3 pictures. Arrange the days from the fewest cookies sold to the most cookies sold.
A bar graph shows votes for the best story. Story A: 8, Story B: 20, Story C: 14, Story D: 5. Arrange the stories from the most votes to the fewest votes to find the ranking.
A table shows the number of stars earned by four children. Meena: 22, Neel: 30, Ojas: 18, Priti: 26. Arrange from the least stars to the most stars.
